Eerie, discordant chords drifted from another room: A trio was practicing. Youre doomed, they seemed to be singing.

title: With Hotels Becoming Social Spots, More Private Spaces for Guests
description: In an industry challenged by Airbnb and other home-sharing competitors, hotels are happy to attract local laptop tappers and cocktail crowds to their lobbies. But public popularity risks frustrating guests, who may be forced to retreat to their rooms, leading to an expansion of guest-only areas including meeting spaces, libraries, quiet rooms and bars.

title: #MeToo Called for an Overhaul. Are Workplaces Really Changing?
description: Women have spoken. Men have fallen. Corporations are nervous. But are American workplaces making real progress in curbing sexual harassment?

title: Trump Just Pushed the World Trade Organization Toward Irrelevance
description: GENEVA  The handsome stone edifice that serves as the headquarters for the World Trade Organization rises like a fortress over Lake Geneva, projecting an air of impregnability. But lately the institution looks vulnerable, sowing worries that global commerce itself may be in jeopardy.

title: Springtime Changes at the Airport
description: It may not feel like it in certain parts of the country, but its finally spring, and changes are underway at the nations airports, including apps that allow travelers to order food and have it delivered directly to their departure gate, the expansion of biometric boarding using facial recognition technology, and higher execution fees for certain United States passport applicants. Below, a look at the latest developments and coming changes.

title: How Nasdaq C.E.O. Adena Friedman Beat the Odds on Wall Street
description: It can be notoriously difficult for women to thrive on Wall Street. Adena Friedman says that hasnt been the case for her.

title: Gary Sanchez Is One of Baseballs Best Catchers, but Theres a Catch
description: TAMPA, Fla.  It is not necessary to bleed pinstripe blue to argue that Gary Sanchez of the Yankees, after his first full season in the major leagues, is poised to become the undisputed best catcher in baseball. He hit more home runs (33) and drove in more runs (90) than any other catcher in baseball last season despite missing a month with a biceps injury, and his .876 on-base-plus-slugging percentage was the best for anyone at the position in the American League.

title: Houston Speculators Make a Fast Buck From Storms Misery
description: HOUSTON  The yard signs appeared almost immediately. Canyon Gate was still in ruins, its streets strewn with moldy furniture, the stench of rot everywhere. But somehow, someone had managed to plant dozens, maybe hundreds of them across the tiny Houston suburb. One proclaimed Dump Your Home! Another, stuck into the dirt, read Flood Damage? We Can Help.

title: Harry Reid Bids Washington Goodbye: Shake My Head Is All I Can Do
description: WASHINGTON  Harry Reid knows off the top of his head that 351 is the DirecTV channel for C-Span coverage of the Senate at his home in Nevada. But he says he rarely turns to it.

title: Finding a Home After a Fire: It Feels Like Your Life Is on Pause
description: Gawayne and Kadian Blake emerged from another interview for an apartment, again empty-handed.

title: Will the Spirit of Burning Man Art Survive in Museums?
description: WASHINGTON  At the end of the summer, for one week only, hundreds of giant fantastical sculptures and whimsical roving vehicles appear, then disappear like a shimmering mirage in the Nevada desert. Were talking about Burning Man, the notoriously free-spirited annual spectacle that has occupied a dry lake bed outside Reno for nearly 30 years.

title: Firefighter Dies in a Harlem Fire on Film Set
description: A New York firefighter was killed and two others were seriously injured by a fire at a building in Harlem that was being used as a film set, officials said Friday morning.

title: Seth Meyers on Trump vs. Biden: Can You Imagine That Fight?
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous nights highlights that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If youre interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

title: John Bolton, Stocks, France: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: The Failure of H.R. McMaster
description: President Trump has replaced Army Lt. Gen. H. R. McMaster with the ultra-hawk John Bolton as his national security adviser, effective April 9.

title: How Genetics Is Changing Our Understanding of Race
description: In 1942, the anthropologist Ashley Montagu published Mans Most Dangerous Myth: The Fallacy of Race, an influential book that argued that race is a social concept with no genetic basis. A classic example often cited is the inconsistent definition of black. In the United States, historically, a person is black if he has any sub-Saharan African ancestry; in Brazil, a person is not black if he is known to have any European ancestry. If black refers to different people in different contexts, how can there be any genetic basis to it?

title: The White Southern Anti-Trump
description: Last May, Mitch Landrieu, the mayor of New Orleans, delivered one of the most stirring and important speeches of the Trump era without once deigning to mention the presidents name. He spoke after New Orleans pulled down four Confederate monuments, the culmination of a ferocious two-year political fight that included threats, armed right-wing protesters and a car being firebombed.

title: Wall St. Closes Lower, as a U.S.-China Trade War Looms
description: Stocks on Wall Street closed lower on Friday, ending the worst week for the Standard & Poors 500-stock index in two years, as investors weighed a brewing trade war between China and the United States that could hobble an otherwise healthy global economy.

title: A Match Thats Perfectly Imperfect
description: As a teenager growing up in Miami, Rahysa Vargas was always more concerned with serving her community than looking for a boyfriend.

title: A Place of Healing
description: This is it? My 8-year-old daughter, Lydia, pressed her face against the van window. This is the farm?

title: Someone Went Too Far at Friends Seminary, but Who?
description: On Feb. 14, Ben Frisch, in his 34th year teaching at Friends Seminary, a private school in downtown Manhattan was seeking to demonstrate an obtuse angle in an 11th grade math class. Straightening his arm and pointing it outward, he mimicked the Nazi salute and said, Heil Hitler.

title: How to Respond When a Colleague Is Harassing Women
New York Today: The Right to Disconnect
description: Updated, 7:56 a.m.

title: What Its Like to Hear the Desert in Music
description: The composer John Luther Adams won the Pulitzer Prize in 2014 for Become Ocean, a lushly tidal, terrifyingly immersive evocation of nature. The music is not only a description of the sea  it behaves like it, Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim wrote in The New York Times. The music submerged the listener in a swirling, churning wash of sound.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Canker Sores, Coffee and Healthy Flying
description: Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Do Face Masks Really Keep You Healthy?
description: Q. How effective are antimicrobial courtesy masks at preventing the spread of contagious airborne illnesses?

title: Listen to The Daily: Racisms Punishing Reach
description: For decades, Americans have believed that the best way to end racial inequality is to end class inequality. But a landmark 30-year study is debunking that logic.

title: Listen to The Daily: Racisms Punishing Reach
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

title: 150 Whales Beached in Australia, as Rescuers Fight to Save Them
description: HONG KONG  More than 150 whales became stranded on a Western Australia beach, wildlife officials said Friday, as poor weather and the threat of frenzied sharks prevented rescuers from saving scores of them.

title: Misreading Trump: Ally Japan Is Spurned on Tariff Exemptions
description: TOKYO  For Japan, the hits just keep on coming.

title: Goldman Sachs Takes Its Homegrown Talk Show to a Wider Audience
description: Goldman Sachs has already made moves to reach Main Street, including creating a consumer lending company and having its chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, become a minor Twitter celebrity.

title: Dropboxs First-Day Pop Should Give Investors Pause: DealBook Briefing
description: Good Friday. Heres what were watching:

title: Three Billboards Call Out Sexual Abuse
description: Kat Sullivan was on a plane to Orlando, Fla., in February when she watched Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri for the first time, a movie about a woman who puts pressure on the local police to find her daughters killer by renting out a series of giant advertising signs.

title: How Jeremy Lyman and Paul Schlader, of Birch Coffee, Spend Their Sundays
description: As co-founders of Birch Coffee, a coffee roaster and local chain of cafes, Jeremy Lyman, 38, and Paul Schlader, 39, are used to being together for most of the day. They have even collaborated on video projects, including Stay Regular, in which they interview favorite customers, and more recently, Birch Brewmasters Present, a comedic take on coffeemaking. The two  who now oversee 10 locations  met in a 12-step recovery program 13 years ago. Mr. Lyman lives in East Harlem with his two pitbulls, Maki and Juna. Mr. Schlader lives on the Upper East Side with his wife Kara, 35, the head of accounts payable for Birch Coffee, and their two children, Ava, 6, and Wesley, 3.

title: E.U. Joins U.K. in Denouncing Russia Over Poisoning of Spy
description: BRUSSELS  Britains prime minister, Theresa May, won greater than expected support from the European Union on Friday over her escalating diplomatic battle with Russia, a significant victory for a leader who has often found herself isolated in Brussels as her country prepares to quit the bloc.

title: French Police Officer Wounded in Hostage Standoff Dies
description: PARIS  A French police officer who was badly wounded on Friday after taking the place of a gunmans hostage has died from his injuries, Interior Minister Grard Collomb said on Saturday.

title: This Week: Czannes Portraits, The Winters Tale, FXs Take on the Getty Kidnapping
description: New TV shows, museum openings, film releases and concerts  its a lot to keep track of. Let us help you. For the week of March 25, seven events in New York and elsewhere not to be missed:

title: Vote Fraud Crusader Kris Kobach Takes His Case to Court, and to Kansas Voters
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan.  Day after day, Kris W. Kobach, the secretary of state of Kansas, grilled people on the witness stand about voter fraud. From behind a courtroom lectern, he questioned the effectiveness of national election law. Sometimes he endured verbal lashings on proper legal procedure from the exasperated judge.

title: Yes, John Bolton Really Is That Dangerous
description: The good thing about John Bolton, President Trumps new national security adviser, is that he says what he thinks.

title: John Bolton Has No Moderating Tendencies
description: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.

title: California Today: Bullet Train Is Not Top Priority, a Candidate for Governor Says
description: Good morning.

title: Giving Videos a Window of Their Own
description: Q. How do you do picture-in-picture video with Safari on a Mac?

title: Review: In Midnight Sun, the Dawn of Romance Can Be Fatal
description: In Midnight Sun, a life-threatening illness inspires a gilded fairy tale. This tour of high school heartbreak follows Katie (Bella Thorne), a wide-eyed teenager who has xeroderma pigmentosum, a condition that renders her dangerously sensitive to ultraviolet light. Although xeroderma pigmentosum is actually a disease, Midnight Sun forgoes realism, exaggerating the risks of Katies illness to portray even the slightest exposure to sunlight as a cause of fatal neurodegeneration.

title: Polish Women Protest Proposed Abortion Ban (Again)
description: WARSAW  To Magda, giving birth would have meant inflicting a slow death. Her unborn child had a rare genetic syndrome that causes severe, fatal birth defects.

title: Trump Signs Spending Bill, Reversing Veto Threat and Avoiding Government Shutdown
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump, hours after threatening to veto a $1.3 trillion spending bill and throwing the capital into turmoil, signed it into law on Friday, yielding to advisers and Republican leaders who urged him against manufacturing a government shutdown crisis.

title: Deadly Attack at French Supermarket
description: A gunman in the town of Trbes, in southwest France, killed three people and took hostages. He said he was acting on behalf of the Islamic State. He was killed by the police.

title: Bolton Was Early Beneficiary of Cambridge Analyticas Facebook Data
description: WASHINGTON  The political action committee founded by John R. Bolton, President Trumps incoming national security adviser, was one of the earliest customers of Cambridge Analytica, which it hired specifically to develop psychological profiles of voters with data harvested from tens of millions of Facebook profiles, according to former Cambridge employees and company documents.

title: Getting Real: When War Films Went to the Trenches
description: Verisimilitude is always an issue with a war film. You cant show war as it really is on the screen, with all the blood and gore, the director Samuel Fuller once observed, suggesting that it might be better to fire real shots over the audiences head and have actual casualties in the theater.

title: Review: In Barry, This Actor Slays Them, Offstage
description: If theres one thing that defines HBO-era TV, its dramas about violent men. If theres a second thing, its comedies set in and around the entertainment business.

title: Burt Reynolds Has Made Mistakes. But He Regrets Nothing.
description: After 60 years in the movie business  five of them, from 1978 to 1982, as the top box-office star in America  Burt Reynolds might appear to be an open book, his every feat, foible, affair and chest hair chronicled so vividly that almost nothing about him could surprise you the way that naked Cosmopolitan centerfold did in 1972.

title: The Americans Goes Dark(er), With Help From a Painter
description: Want to know how The Americans ends? Head to Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Walk toward the East River. Disarm a couple of security doors. Climb a flight of stairs. Find an open door, and enter the studio of Alyssa Monks.

title: Cleaning Tools for a Tiny Apartment
description: I first laid eyes on a countertop dishwasher called Tetra at a consumer electronics convention in Las Vegas a few months ago. Just big enough to hold two place settings, it doesnt require a faucet connection, unlike most other models.

title: Shining a Cleansing Light on Chinas Dark Secrets
description: BEIJING  Shen Zhihua, bon vivant, former businessman, now Chinas foremost Cold War historian, has set himself a near-impossible task. He wants China to peel back its secrets, throw open its archives and tell its citizens what went on between China and the United States, between China and North Korea, and much more.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Good morning. Tejal Rao has a beautiful riff about dried beans in The New York Times Magazine right now, about how she traffics beans home from her travels around the world, auntie-style, rolled up in old plastic bags, concealed between the folded clothes in my suitcase.

title: Globalizations Backlash Is Here, at Just the Wrong Time
description: No one should be surprised that there has been a backlash to globalization, given the scale of disruption that has resulted from more interconnected economies. What is surprising is that it has arrived now.

title: Not Strictly Salad, but Close Enough
description: No matter how beguiling and colorful my salad dreams may be, when the hectic swirl of weeknight dinner begins, I routinely ditch them for plain greens tossed with lemon juice and olive oil. Adding a grated garlic clove to the dressing is the height of my after-work ambitions.

title: Basil Twists Fantastic Feathered World (With Tinsel and Berlioz)
description: Pull, pull, pull! Basil Twist called out the other day as two puppeteers struggled to drag a waterlogged blue curtain out of a five-foot-deep tank filled with 1,000 gallons of water. The tank sat in a bunkerlike room near Canal Street and Sixth Avenue. The rooms owner, Trinity Real Estate, had lent it to Mr. Twist so he could rehearse his musical puppet-reverie Symphonie Fantastique. Now 20 years old, the show returns to the HERE theater, just a few blocks away, for a 12-week run on Thursday.

title: Bringing Disneys European Adventures to American Readers
description: Before there was Euro Disney the theme park, there was Euro Disney the comic books. Now, after more than six decades, the European adventures of Mickey Mouse, Donald Duck and Uncle Scrooge will be released in the United States.

title: American Adults Just Keep Getting Fatter
description: American adults continue to put on the pounds. New data shows that nearly 40 percent of them were obese in 2015 and 2016, a sharp increase from a decade earlier, federal health officials reported Friday.

title: If You Murdered Someone, Would You Know It?
description: UP IN THE AIR: If you murdered someone, would you know it? Thats the premise of Chris Bohjalians new novel, The Flight Attendant, which enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 8. A seasoned flight attendant on a layover in Dubai  a hard-partying, hard-working woman whos also a functioning alcoholic  wakes up one morning to find the Russian businessman next to her dead, his neck sliced open with the shards of a Stoli bottle. Theres a great crimson stain on the pillow, and a slick, still-wet pool on the crisp white sheets. Furred by the previous nights vodka, she doesnt remember what happened.

title: Do We Cover White Christian Attackers Differently? Discuss How We Reported on the Austin Bombings
description: The Reader Center is one way we in the newsroom are trying to connect with you, by highlighting your perspectives and experiences and offering insight into how we work.

title: Bolton the Hawk Gets His Chance
description: To the Editor:

title: Helping Low-Income People: The Cruel Way and the Right Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Something About Parkland Has Been Different: Survivors From 20 Years of Mass Shootings Speak
description: The attack at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., last month was the latest in what seems like an inescapable pattern to proponents of gun safety: gunfire, thoughts and prayers, funerals and public mourning, until the next time.

title: Conflict Is More Profitable Than Peace
description: BAYANGA, Central African Republic  Perhaps the most devastating blow any human can suffer is to lose a child, and Julienne Moada has already lost three. A Pygmy living on the edge of the jungle in what may be the worlds most wretched country, she has borne five children and now cradles little Bruno, a fourth in peril, with fierce devotion and desperation.

title: The Quest for Fair Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: The Crisis in New York City Public Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: What 7 Book Lovers Wore to the Antiquarian Fair
description: The 58th New York Antiquarian Book Fair brought 210 sellers of rare books to the Park Avenue Armory earlier this month. Attendees included such literary luminaries as Gay Talese, Jay McInerney and Fran Lebowitz, who came to inspect precious manuscripts like a first edition of Copernicuss On the Revolutions of Heavenly Spheres, on sale for $2 million. Heres what some of them wore.

title: The Trump Boom Is Making It Harder to See the Next Recession
description: When big shifts like recessions are on the way, economists just arent very good at predicting them.

title: Its a Tough, Dusty Construction Job. She Loves It.
description: Marissa Goodsky, 27, is a concrete mason at McGough in Roseville, Minn.

title: Listen to Dear Sugars
description: What are your options when youre sexually harassed at work? The Sugars advise.

title: Quitting Heroin in the Sunshine State
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla.  I live in Florida, where I have been in treatment for drug addiction for the last year, through periods of recovery and occasions of relapse.

title: M.L.B. 2018: What to Expect This Season
description: The Major League Baseball seasons begins on Thursday, with six new managers at the helm, a pair of notable position changes and several milestones within reach. Heres a look at what to expect this season:

title: Why Chinas Response to Trumps Tariffs Is So Muted
description: BEIJING  In a tit-for-tat trade battle with the United States, Chinas response has so far been restrained.

title: U.S. Charges 9 Iranians in Huge Theft of Intellectual Property
description: WASHINGTON  Nine Iranians stole secrets from American government agencies, universities and companies in a yearslong cyberattack, federal law enforcement officials said on Friday, calling out Tehran amid fears that the Trump administration will dismantle the Iran nuclear deal.

title: 20 Years After the Shooting on the Playground
description: When I was 12 years old I went to five funerals in one week. My classmates and I sat clutching one another on crowded church pews listening to Celine Dions My Heart Will Go On, wearing thick white ribbons on our chests like scarlet As. We were thrust into a small and terrible survivors club.

title: Five Things I Learned on My Quebec Road Trip: The Canada Letter
description: Hi! Its Dan Bilefsky. Its been a frenetic 11 days on my road trip through Quebec. I ended the trip in proud and scenic Saguenay, an important center for forestry and aluminum, and am now returning home to Montreal.

title: Trading Cards: A Hobby That Became a Multimillion-Dollar Investment
description: Brady Hill used his skills for buying and selling baseball cards to purchase his first car and to pay his way through Louisiana State University.

title: H. Wayne Huizenga, Owner of Teams and a Business Empire, Dies at 80
description: H. Wayne Huizenga, the entrepreneur who expanded Blockbuster video and AutoNation into vast enterprises and owned three South Florida sports teams, died on Thursday night at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 80.

title: March for Our Lives: The Students Arrive in Washington
description: The kids are in town.

title: We Asked 7 Lawyers to Untangle the Broadway Fight Over To Kill a Mockingbird
description: Harper Lee was a literary celebrity. Aaron Sorkin is a screenwriting superstar. And now the two  by proxy  are locked in a battle over who should shape the content in Mr. Sorkins stage adaptation of Ms. Lees famous novel, To Kill a Mockingbird.

title: College Coaches Cannot Be Contained
description: ATLANTA  Drew Speraw, a Kansas State assistant coach, found himself in an unenviable position near the end of the Wildcats tight win over the University of Maryland, Baltimore County, last Sunday: He had to physically grab his boss.

title: Sacramento Kings Owner Calls Stephon Clark Killing a Horrific Tragedy
description: The owner of the N.B.A.s Sacramento Kings took the court after the teams game against the Atlanta Hawks on Thursday night, saying he would try to bring everybody together after the fatal shooting of Stephon Clark, an unarmed black man, by the Sacramento police last weekend.

title: Dropbox Shares Leap in I.P.O., and Silicon Valley Smiles
description: Dropbox, the file-sharing company and Silicon Valley darling, had a strong market debut Friday, a reassuring sign for the technology industry and for the investors who have billions locked up in other highly valued but privately held start-ups.

title: Zell Miller, Feisty Democrat Who Sided With G.O.P., Is Dead at 86
description: Zell Miller, a cantankerously independent politician from the mountains of northern Georgia who disdained backslapping and baby-kissing as he snarled at journalists and battled fellow Democrats in his four years as a United States senator, died on Friday morning at his home in Young Harris, Ga. He was 86.

title: Champions Behind the Wire
description: It takes 10 minutes to drive from the military checkpoint, where anyone who has a pass to the city must stop, to an ice-filled stadium called Trud (Work).

title: Single? No Kids? Dont Fret: How to Plan Care in Your Later Years
description: Sarah Peveler lacks a support system that many older people count on: their adult children.

title: Trevor Winkfield Brings Optical Heat to His Latest Gallery Show
description: Born in Britain in 1944, Trevor Winkfield has lived in New York since 1969 and exhibited here almost as long. For decades, he has cultivated a style of Formalist Pop Surrealism that balances between fine and commercial art. His precedents include the proto-Pop paintings of Gerald Murphy; Paul Outerbridges advertising photography; and Picabias mechanical portraits which Mr. Winkfield might be said to have fleshed out.

title: A Crisp Cool-Weather Twist for a Classic Summer Salad
description: A satisfying salad of tuna and beans is a Mediterranean favorite, often served as a meal in warm weather. In my favorite version, the main ingredients  rich tuna and creamy beans  are accented with red wine vinegar, tomato and onion, finished with a flourish of extra-virgin olive oil.

title: Review: Vittorio Grigolo Is the Reason to See the Mets Lucia
description: In most performances of Donizettis Lucia di Lammermoor, its hard not to feel a little sorry for the lead tenor during the final scene. This tormented moment for the character Edgardo is one of the composers most inspired creations, but it immediately follows Lucias famous mad scene  usually the showstopper.

title: Elon Musk Joins #DeleteFacebook With a Barrage of Tweets
description: Elon Musk and Mark Zuckerberg have clashed on artificial intelligence, space travel and the direction of technology.

title: This Woman Makes a Living Destroying Jeans and Fixing Houses
description: LOS ANGELES  In the neighborhood of Angelino Heights, often called the first suburb of Los Angeles, stands a small Victorian house built in the late 1890s. A duplex, it is overgrown with white roses and white oleander. An enormous guava tree spread its branches across a window. A 100-year-old lemon tree that looked as if it had never been pruned staked claim to the back.

title: Nicolas Sarkozy and the Libya Investigation: The Key Questions
description: PARIS  Nicolas Sarkozy, the flamboyant former French president who had hoped to revive his political career, is facing a  formal investigation over allegations that his 2007 campaign received illegal funding from the Libyan strongman Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Ready for Season 6 of The Americans? Heres What to Remember
description: When The Americans returns to FX for its final season on March 28, the action will have leapt ahead three years to 1987, leaving us with a lot to remember from all of the spy games weve witnessed till now. Philip and Elizabeth Jennings have come a long way without their true identities as Russian spies being discovered  so many close calls, so many wigs  but with two moody teenagers on their hands, a host of dubious sources and an F.B.I. agent living across the street, how much longer can their luck last?

title: Ready for Season 6 of The Americans? Heres What to Remember
description: The final season of the critically-acclaimed drama starts Wednesday, March 28. Where did we leave off? Its complicated.

title: After Another Week of Chaos, Trump Repairs to Palm Beach. No One Knows What Comes Next.
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.  President Trump decamped to his oceanfront estate here on Friday after a head-spinning series of presidential decisions on national security, trade and the budget that left the capital reeling and his advisers nervous about what comes next.

title: Scene-Stealing Tenor: The Weeks Best Classical Music Moments on YouTube
description: Our critics and reporters offer a glimpse of whats moved and delighted them on YouTube. Read the rest of our classical music coverage here.

title: Despite Trump Threat, N.E.A and N.E.H Are Spared in Spending Bill
description: Arts organizations around the country can breathe a sigh of relief.

title: John Waterss Art to Go on Display in Baltimore in October
description: After serving for years as the backdrop of John Waters films like Hairspray and Cry Baby, Baltimore will host a retrospective of Mr. Waterss visual art.

title: At Hamburger Central, Antibiotics for Cattle That Arent Sick
description: Ben Holland holds a Mason jar, tilting it slightly to show the powdery 90 milligrams of the antibiotic tylosin inside.

title: Ava Nirui Gives Bootleg a Fashion Twist
description: Name: Ava Nirui

title: Trumps Tariffs: Another Retreat From the Postwar World Order
description: We would probably be kidding ourselves if we treated President Trumps imposition of sweeping new tariffs on China as motivated by some grand ideology or seismic shift in a War of Ideas.

title: The Dramatic Last Hours as Agents Stalked the Austin Bomber
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  It was past midnight when the call finally came crackling over the radios of agents pursuing the man who had been terrorizing Austin with his homemade bombs. An officer had sighted an aging red Nissan Pathfinder in the parking lot of a Courtyard by Marriott hotel in suburban Round Rock, Tex.

title: Eli Leon, 82, Dies; Champion of African-American Quilt Makers
description: Eli Leon, a psychologist, writer and collector and self-taught scholar of African-American quilts, who helped bring attention to the field and especially the quilts of Rosie Lee Tompkins, died on March 6 in Emeryville, Calif. He was 82.

title: China Brings Warm Words to U.N., and Rights Activists Feel a Chill
description: GENEVA  The resolution passed by the United Nations top human rights body on Friday seemed innocuous, if obscurely worded in places.

title: Make T Something | Beth Bugdaycay
description: The co-founder of the fine jewelry line Foundrae makes a bespoke necklace out of newspaper and string.

title: A Downtown Jewelry Store That Celebrates the Personal
description: Foundrae, the fine jewelry line Beth Bugdaycay launched with her husband, Murat, in 2015, is all about the mix. Wearers stack rings, pair enameled charms and create custom, 18-karat gold pieces that pull from the brands 60-strong lexicon of symbols  a triangle for transformation, a lions head for strength, a Bowen knot for true love. Foundraes first store, at 52 Lispenard Street in downtown Manhattan, takes a similarly eclectic approach: An antique roll-top jewelers bench (where shoppers can see items get soldered) and a suite of 1970s-era rounded leather armchairs by Giancarlo Piretti for Castelli sit alongside contemporary pieces such as a moody, eight-by-ten-foot landscape painted by Tyler Hays of the furniture company BDDW. To me its totally Hudson River Valley, says Bugdaycay, a longtime admirer of American arts and crafts. (Before she was a designer, she was a kid growing up in the border town of Brownsville, Tex., and paying close attention to her parents, who made traditional rocking chairs.)

title: Budget Deal in Congress Includes Help for Affordable Housing
description: When Congress voted last year to sharply reduce corporate income taxes, it undermined the nations largest subsidized housing program. This weeks federal spending compromise may help shore it up.

title: Oleg Tabakov, Revered Russian Actor and Teacher, Is Dead at 82
description: I remember once I declared love, the visitor told a room full of acting students at the Trinity School on Manhattans Upper West Side. It was spring. We were on a boulevard. She had on a lovely white coat. I wanted to start talking, and I suddenly felt that my top lip got stuck to my nose.

title: Suicide Attack in Afghanistan Kills at Least 14 at Wrestling Match
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide attacker drove a car full of explosives into a crowd leaving an evening wrestling match on Friday in southern Afghanistan, killing at least 14 and wounding 42, according to Afghan government officials.

title: The Joys of Reading
description: Fund-raisers were held for Literacy Partners, the Frick Collection and the Endometriosis Foundation of America.

title: When Republicans Rejected John Bolton
description: John R. Bolton, chosen by President Trump to be his new national security adviser, does not need the Senates endorsement to succeed H. R. McMaster in the job. But in 2005, the extraordinary refusal to confirm his nomination to be President George W. Bushs ambassador to the United Nations by a Republican-controlled committee is worth revisiting for what it revealed about Mr. Bolton and what it may portend for our national security.

title: Chris Kelly and Brian Gionta Go From the Olympics to the N.H.L. Playoff Hunt
description: Shortly after captaining Canadas mens hockey team to a bronze medal and attending the closing ceremony at the Winter Olympics in South Korea, Chris Kelly boarded a 12-hour flight to Toronto.

title: Unique Identifiers in Animal DNA
description: Q. Are humans the only creatures with individual DNA fingerprints? What about other species?

title: Donte DiVincenzo and Trevon Duval Give Delaware Hoops a Moment
description: WILMINGTON, Del.  Delaware is known for its association with a recent vice president of the United States, the du Pont family and friendly bankruptcy laws. For its basketball pedigree? Not so much.

title: The Playlist: Shawn Mendes Shows His Scars, and 9 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos  and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. This week, Snail Mail expresses some self-doubt, A Boogie Wit Da Hoodie balances love and lust and live recordings of Miles Davis and John Coltrane are released.

title: Olly Wilson, 80, Dies; Composer Meshed African and Western Music
description: Olly Wilson, an adventurous composer who integrated African, African-American and electronic rhythms, riffs and sounds into Western classical music conventions, died on March 12 in Oakland, Calif. He was 80.

title: Craigslist Drops Personal Ads Because of Sex Trafficking Bill
description: Looking for love or a casual encounter? Youll have to find it someplace other than Craigslist.

title: Weve Had Enough, Says Perus New President
description: LIMA, Peru  Martn Vizcarra, who had been Perus first vice president and ambassador to Canada, was sworn in as the nations president on Friday afternoon, after Congress accepted the resignation of his predecessor, Pedro Pablo Kuczynski, who was brought down by scandals involving graft, vote-buying and a looming impeachment.

title: 5 Things T Editors Like Right Now
description: Next Friday, master sushi chef Nozomu Abe (formerly of Sushiden) will open his very first restaurant, Sushi Noz, which will serve traditional omakase on Manhattans Upper East Side. Masterminded by the Kyoto-based architecture firm Sankakuya, known for restoring ancient shrines and temples in Japan, the minimalist pale-wood space was constructed exclusively using traditional joinery techniques and centuries-old Japanese timber: hinoki (Japanese cypress) for the eight-person dining room and ash for a smaller six-person private room. The former will also feature a 200-year-old sushi counter that was aged for 40 years in chef Nozs hometown of Hokkaido.

title: Ts Design Issue: This Is Us
description: Before I turned 17, my family had moved eight times. In Honolulu, we lived in my maternal grandparents house, a wooden plantation-style 1940s bungalow shaded from the late-afternoon sun by a copse of pink and red torch ginger that had grown so tall and dense that its leaves poked through the sea-glass-green jalousies. In New York we lived in an apartment building overlooking the East River, where all the residents with children would leave their front doors open during the day, turning the floors into a honeycombed communal space for us kids to inhabit. In Texas, before we moved into a house, we lived in a one-bedroom apartment, my brother and I sleeping in the living room on soft cotton chairs that unfolded into futon-like mattresses.

title: Arctic Sea Ice Missed a Record Low This Winter. Barely.
description: The maximum extent of Arctic sea ice cover this winter was the second-lowest since satellite record-keeping began, researchers said Friday.

title: Tariff Battle: Where the U.S. and Chinese Moves May Lead
description: President Trump pushed forward with a two-pronged trade offensive this week, enacting tariffs on imported aluminum and steel on Friday, a day after announcing levies on up to $60 billion in Chinese goods. The target of both actions is China, a country that Mr. Trump has called an economic enemy of the United States.

title: Gary Lincoff, 75, Dies; Spread the Joy of Mushrooms Far and Wide
description: Gary Lincoff, a self-taught mycologist whose contagious enthusiasm turned him into a pied piper of mushrooms, died on March 16 in Manhattan. He was 75.

title: Two Underdogs Join the Party, Linked by More Than a Conference
description: In the swirling postgame joy, Central Michigan Coach Sue Guevara knew she had to make an important phone call. Her Chippewas, seeded 11th in the N.C.A.A. womens basketball tournament, had just defeated third-seeded Ohio State, 95-78, to advance to the round of 16 for the first time.

title: Even by Trump Standards, a Lot Has Happened This Week. Let Us Catch You Up.
description: There has been a lot of news this week, and its hard to keep track of it all. Including White House staff shake-ups  President Trump is on to his third national security adviser  and major trade action against China, here are six of the biggest stories driving American politics this week. (And some links to other stories if you want to read further.)

title: Justice Dept. Proposes Banning Bump Stocks, Setting Aside Its Own Recommendations
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Jeff Sessions said on Friday that the Justice Department was proposing to ban so-called bump stocks through regulations rather than wait for Congress to act, a move that defies recommendations by federal law enforcement officials and could subject the department to litigation from gun rights groups.

title: For the U.S. and China, a Technology Cold War Thats Freezing Over
description: A cold war is being waged across the worlds most advanced industries. And it just got a lot chillier.

title: Why Cant Dying Patients Get the Drugs They Want?
description: At first glance, a bill passed by the House of Representatives this week seems like the kind of thing anyone could get behind.

title: Open Thread: This Week in Style News
description: Each week, the Open Thread newsletter will offer a look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. The latest newsletter appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Ubers Self-Driving Cars Were Struggling Before Arizona Crash
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Ubers robotic vehicle project was not living up to expectations months before a self-driving car operated by the company struck and killed a woman in Tempe, Ariz.

title: Betty Ann Bowser, Versatile TV Newswoman, Is Dead at 73
description: Betty Ann Bowser, one of televisions most prominent newswomen for years as a correspondent for CBS and then the PBS NewsHour, died on March 16 at her home in Ajijic, Mexico. She was 73.

title: John Bolton, China, Uber: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Egypts Election Should Be a Lock. So Why Is President Sisi Worried?
description: CAIRO  Days before Egypts presidential election, President Abdel Fattah el-Sisis beaming visage adorns billboards across Egypt. His rivals are in jail, the news media is in his pocket and his sole challenger  a politician so obscure many Egyptians would struggle to name him  hasnt bothered to campaign.

title: City Never Sleeps, Yet Number of Trains at Off-Peak Hours Decline
description: Carrying a wig in rollers in her purse, Ashley Callahan, who works as a theater wigmaker, stood aboard an N train on Friday, detailing her lopsided commute. During the morning rush, she heads from Upper Manhattan to the theater district with hordes of other commuters. But at night, when she stays past the curtain call to brush up an updo or rethread a toupee, she waits endlessly on a platform, craning her neck for trains that take forever to arrive.

title: De Blasio Could End Up a Witness in Case He Sought to Avoid
description: For more than a year, Mayor Bill de Blasio tried his best to distance himself from Harendra Singh, a wealthy donor who was cooperating with federal authorities in a Brooklyn-based corruption investigation of the mayors fund-raising practices.

title: Ohio States Secret Weapon? An Assistant Coach
description: His close coaching colleagues call it the Killer factor, or Killer karma. More than one has noted, with admiration, that championships seem to follow him around.

title: Blaze Erupts Beneath a Movie Set in Harlem, and a Firefighter Dies Rushing In
description: Firefighter Michael Davidson was a nozzle man  hed be at the front of the hose line, leading the charge into a burning building. And thats where he was, one last time, on Thursday night, after his engine company, No. 69, pulled up near a once-storied jazz club in Harlem that had a fire raging in the cellar beneath it.

title: The New Superpredator Myth
description: The criminologist John DiIulio sparked panic in 1995 when he predicted there would be an explosion of juvenile superpredators in the coming years, resulting in widespread violence. His baseless theory was wrong; youth crime has fallen dramatically ever since.

title: Spanish Judge Jails 5 Catalan Leaders in a Blow to Secessionist Movement
description: BARCELONA, Spain  A Spanish Supreme Court judge on Friday ordered five Catalan politicians to be detained without bail, a decision that reignited tensions in the region as the central government struggled to quell the secessionist movement in Catalonia.

title: Zuckerberg Takes Steps to Calm Facebook Employees
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For the past week, Mark Zuckerberg has grappled with a backlash from lawmakers, regulators and users over Facebooks mishandling of data privacy. He has also had to face another restive group: his own employees.

title: British Authorities Search Offices of Cambridge Analytica
description: British investigators on Friday night searched the London offices of Cambridge Analytica, the data-analytics company that harvested data from 50 million Facebook users to develop psychological profiles on behalf of political campaigns, including that of President Trump.

title: Firefighter Killed in Harlem Blaze Supported Others With Vigor
description: When new firefighters arrived at his firehouse in Harlem, Michael Davidson would take it upon himself to supplement their training with advice on how to handle themselves at fires and even how to exercise. When a colleagues daughter needed help, he organized a fund-raiser. And just a few days ago, after another winter storm, he went around to neighbors houses with a snowblower.

title: Friday Night Music: Lucius at Town Hall
description: An explanation for readers who may not have followed my old blog: In my later years I have found myself, unexpectedly, a fan of indie music, and began running a regular feature I called Friday night music, with performance videos by bands I like  sometimes ones I shot myself, sometimes pulled off others.

title: Novak Djokovics Swoon Continues at the Miami Open
description: MIAMI  Novak Djokovic has gone from being the most dominant tennis player in the world to sounding like an existential philosopher, and not many of those have ever won a tennis tournament.

title: Toxic Gases Blamed for Iowa Familys Death in Mexican Condo
description: Four members of an Iowa family whose bodies were recently found in a condominium in Mexico died of inhalation of toxic gases, the authorities said on Saturday.

title: Lawrence K. Grossman, Head of PBS and Then NBC News, Dies at 86
description: Lawrence K. Grossman, who as president of PBS doubled the length of the MacNeil/Lehrer Report, its signature news program, then headed NBC News, where he dealt unhappily with budget austerity after it came under General Electrics ownership, died on Friday at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 86.

title: Trumps Objections Require Some Corrections
description: WASHINGTON  As President Trump prepared on Friday to sign a $1.3 trillion spending bill, just hours after threatening to veto it, he offered a few misleading and selectively worded claims to explain why he was reluctantly authorizing the legislation.

title: It Was Not Herself That Killed Them, Sister Testifies in Nanny Trial
description: A few days before Yoselyn Ortega plunged a knife into two young children she had been hired to babysit, she woke in the dead of night and started throwing pots and pans at the walls of the kitchen in her familys Upper Manhattan apartment. Her sister rushed in to restrain her.

title: John Bolton Is Right About the U.N.
description: In 1994, John Bolton said that if the United Nations Secretariat building in New York lost 10 stories, it wouldnt make a bit of difference. The quote makes an appearance nearly every time Boltons critics compile a hit parade of his alleged infamies.

title: Quotation of the Day: American Allies React: The Whole World Should Be Concerned
description: People are trying to avoid appearing terrified, but people are deeply concerned.

title: The Tragedy of Hubert Humphrey
description: On Feb. 17, 1965, Vice President Hubert Humphrey sent President Lyndon B. Johnson a memorandum stating the United States must begin an exit strategy in Vietnam: It is always hard to cut losses. But the Johnson administration is in a stronger position to do so now than any administration in this century. Johnson had trounced Barry Goldwater in the 1964 election  and thus, no longer had to prove he was tough on Communism  and the conflict had not developed into a full-blown war. Nineteen sixty-five is the year of minimum political risk, Humphrey wrote.

title: They Cant Wait: Yankees Try Leading Off With Aaron Judge
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Move over, Ichiro Suzuki. Step aside, Pete Rose. Slide down, Maury Wills.

title: Biden and Trump Talk Trash
description: So, do you think Joe Biden is too old to be president?

title: Corrections: March 24, 2018
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Homer and Others
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  If youre a grizzled veteran of weekend puzzles, youre familiar with Byron Walden. This is his 59th Saturday grid, and hes got nine Sundays to boot. Todays is suitably treacherous. Mr. Walden notes below that hes halfway to a prestigious record, constructor of the most Saturday Times puzzles, but for all we solvers know, Mr. Walden could go on to make a thousand of these infernal flummoxers. Enjoy!

title: Arming Teachers
description: It was a blistering day in June 2015, and the sun beat down relentlessly. The only shelter was a small makeshift shed, hidden behind an overgrown embankment next to an almost inaccessible stretch of railroad tracks in a remote area of central Ohio. It was the kind of place that youd never find without a detailed map, one I typically wouldnt, as a woman, visit alone. But there were more than 20 women and men there when I arrived, all of them heavily armed.

title: Villanova Breaks Free of West Virginia in the Second Half to Win
description: BOSTON  After Villanova watched University of Maryland, Baltimore County, complete its unforgettable upset over top-seeded Virginia from a hotel room in Pittsburgh, Coach Jay Wright said nothing to his team.

title: Kansas Survives a Late Scare From Clemson to Advance, 80-76
description: OMAHA  Kansas most important player is the senior guard Devonte Graham. But entering Fridays round-of-16 matchup against a physical Clemson team, the Jayhawks X factor was the sophomore 7-footer Udoka Azubuike, whose knee injury had kept him out of the Big 12 tournament and limited him in the N.C.A.A. tournaments first two rounds.

title: Highlights for a March Weekend From Opinion
description: Here is a selection of some notable recent pieces, including several on the debate over gun laws in the wake of a mass shooting at a high school in Parkland, Fla.

title: After the March, Follow This Gun Reform Battle Plan
description: It has been 38 days since the mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla.; 174 days since the shooting at a concert in Las Vegas; 1,011 days since the killings at a church in Charleston, S.C.; and 1,926 since the tragedy at Sandy Hook Elementary School. Ten days ago, students organized a nationwide school walkout to demonstrate their outrage about these and other shootings.

title: Trump Approves New Limits on Transgender Troops in the Military
description: WASHINGTON  Transgender troops who are currently in the United States military may remain in the ranks, the White House said late Friday, but the Pentagon could require them to serve according to their gender at birth.

title: Whats on TV Saturday: Hope & Fury and the Kids Choice Awards
description: A new documentary looks at the role of media in the Civil Rights era. And Nickelodeons annual awards show is still sliming after all these years.

title: Duke Survives a Battle With the Syracuse Zone
description: OMAHA  About seven minutes into the N.C.A.A. tournament game between second-seeded Duke and 11th-seeded Syracuse on Friday, the Blue Devils all-world freshman big man, Marvin Bagley III, got the ball inside. He was quickly swallowed by Syracuses zone, but somehow managed to kick it out to Dukes lone senior, Grayson Allen. Allen nailed a 3-pointer and pointed at Bagley in acknowledgment.

title: Texas Tech Advances Past Purdues Diminished Frontcourt
description: BOSTON  With all that was at stake on Friday, the key numbers that Purdue fans were focused on were 1-26.2.

title: This Is What I Do When I Hear the Bombs Explode
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

title: North and South Korea to Hold Preparatory Talks for Summit Meeting
description: SEOUL, South Korea  High-ranking officials from North and South Korea will meet on the countries border next week to prepare for the inter-Korean summit meeting planned for late next month, the South said on Saturday.

title: How Bananas Can Explain Trade Wars
description: The banana wars were spats that escalated, tariff by tariff, into a decades-long dispute between the United States and the European Union.

title: How Trade Wars Begin
description: The Trump administration this week raised fears of a trade war after it authorized a series of tariffs explicitly  and implicitly  aimed at China.

title: Support for Gun Control Seems Strong. But It May Be Softer Than It Looks.
description: When you ask Americans in a poll whether they support universal background checks for gun purchases, huge majorities say yes.

title: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
description: In like a lion, out like a lamb, its said of March. As we move toward the close of the month, here are some of our top reads of the week to see you through. Cheers to spring days ahead.

title: Humans of Quebec: Portraits of Those I Met on My Road Trip
description: The faces of Quebec are as eclectic as the province itself. I recently spent 10 days on the road rediscovering Quebec, where I was born, after nearly three decades living away. Here are some of the people I met along the way, including an Algonquin D.J., the doorman at Quebec Citys grandest hotel, a 27-year-old left-wing separatist leader, a 91-year-old conservationist and a detective novelist.

title: At the Whitby in New York, Warm Service, Sophisticated Design
description: From $595 including Wi-Fi.

title: A Peruvian Chef Who Conquered the World Scales Higher Heights
description: Taking destination dining to new heights, a celebrated Peruvian chef has just hung out his shingle 11,706 feet above sea level, where the entirety of his street address is ascending 500 meters from the Archaeological Complex of Moray. Yet despite the enigmatic coordinates, and the fact that the nearest villages are all but concealed from the outside world, every taxista within a 100-mile radius will soon know these back roads by heart.

title: The Former Khmer Rouge Slave Who Blew the Whistle on Wells Fargo
description: After Duke Tran escaped from slavery, but before he became a millionaire, he was a Wells Fargo employee.

title: March for Our Lives Highlights: Students Protesting Guns Say Enough Is Enough
In Swedens Preschools, Boys Learn to Dance and Girls Learn to Yell
description: STOCKHOLM  Something was wrong with the Penguins, the incoming class of toddlers at the Seafarers Preschool, in a wooded suburb south of Stockholm.

title: Listen to Dear Sugars: Sexual Harassment in the Workplace
description: The #MeToo Moment deluged the Dear Sugars inbox with letters about sexual harassment in the workplace. In the final episode in our series on sexual consent, the Sugars read some of these letters and discuss what happens when non-consensual sexual attention moves from the private to the public realm.

title: All Men Are Guilty, Says Mega-Mogul Barry Diller
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Barry Diller knows your weaknesses.

title: Siri, Alexa and That Google Gal Will Get You Only So Far
description: In 2015, when the Silicon Valley C.E.O. Mike Chen was working on a health care start-up, he and his colleagues had one of those light bulb moments regarding digital assistance.

title: Confirm or Deny: Barry Diller
description: Maureen Dowd: You wish I.A.C. owned Goop.

title: And in This Corner: A Rival From Japan Takes On the Pro Wrestling Establishment
description: In the history of professional wrestling tag teams, the billionaire Mark Cuban and his Japanese business partners make for one of the industrys more dissonant stables.

title: Trumps Tariffs Keep Allies, Markets and Industry Guessing
description: WASHINGTON  President Trumps flurry of trade moves this past week raised uncertainty and confusion among financial markets, trading partners, lawmakers and American industry, prompting many to ask what, exactly, his endgame might be.

title: Powerful Indian Politician Gets 14-Year Prison Sentence for Embezzlement
description: A powerful Indian politician was sentenced on Saturday to 14 years in prison for embezzling 37 million rupees from a state governments treasury while he was the states top elected official.

title: She Finally Gave the Office Nice Guy a Chance
description: Shifa Fahim Mahmood and Ramy Mohsen Fakhr were married March 23 at the Islamic Cultural Center of New York in Manhattan. Sheikh Saad Jalloh led a Muslim ceremony, called a nikah.

title: He Had the First Line on Stage, She the Last
description: Catherine Sara Schwartz and Daniel Isaac Markowitz are to be married March 25 at Pen Ryn Estate in Bensalem, Pa. Rabbi Jennifer Goldsmith is to officiate.

title: Justice Dept. Revives Push to Mandate a Way to Unlock Phones
description: WASHINGTON  Federal law enforcement officials are renewing a push for a legal mandate that tech companies build tools into smartphones and other devices that would allow access to encrypted data in criminal investigations.

title: When a Buildings Cleaning Products Make a Tenant Miserable
description: Q. I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in the West Village. Every morning, the superintendent, or another worker, mops the entryway with powerful cleaning products. Once a week, workers sprinkle a potent powder on the hallway rugs to vacuum. Since I work from home, I am constantly exposed to these toxic products. I have complained to the super and building management, to no avail. (The super even told me the owner hopes that I will move out because my lease is rent-stabilized.) I have read about the health hazards of cleaning products. Imagine what its like being forced to inhale these fumes daily! What can be done to protect my health?

title: Transgender Workers Gain New Protection Under Court Ruling
description: WASHINGTON  Employers are moving to adopt or strengthen policies to prevent bias against transgender people after the latest in a series of court rulings that have extended protections for an increasingly diverse work force.

title: Our 20 Most Popular Salmon Recipes
description: From burgers to slow-roasted citrus salmon with herb salad (above), here are the recipes readers love. (For guidance on what to buy and how to cook it, check out our salmon guide.)

title: UConn Women Beat Duke With the Help of a Former Blue Devil
description: ALBANY  It was a rare move for Connecticut womens basketball, accepting a high-profile transfer instead of fully stocking the roster with top-rated recruits from high school.

title: He Left Soviet Army for Afghan Life 35 Years Ago. Now, He Sees Russians Return.
description: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan  When the Soviet Army pulled out of Afghanistan decades ago, it left behind rusty tanks, the wreckage of helicopters and a Ukrainian man who now goes by the name Nek Mohammad.

title: Creating a Reading List for a New Literary Moment
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

title: In France, Officer Slain After Swapping Places With Hostage Is Hailed as Hero
description: PARIS  Swapping places with a woman being held hostage, the French police officer entered the supermarket where a gunman, claiming allegiance to the Islamic State, had already shot and killed two people on Friday.

title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Cryptic crosswords are a unique form of punishment. If you like tricky clues in regular grids, though, you owe yourself to try them. At first, if it seems as if the rules are inscrutable, dont bail out; this is a very popular type of puzzle in other spheres, so theres great, detailed solving information available online (Deb Amlen recommends this guide  try using it as a road map today).

title: A Dying Southern Town Needed a Miracle. Marijuana Came Calling.
description: COTTON PLANT, Ark.  Mayor Willard C. Ryland looked everywhere for salvation for his dying town. He tried luring a vegetable packing company. An Asian carp processor. A Dollar General store. But he struck out again and again.

title: Photos From the March for Our Lives Protests Around the World
description: Crowds gathered in cities across the United States and around the world.

title: Trade and the Cities (Wonkish)
description: Bad policies sometimes lead to interesting economics. For example, the disastrous turn toward austerity after 2009 was a kind of natural experiment that led to an upwelling of good work on the effects of fiscal policy.

title: America First Bears a New Threat: Military Force
description: WASHINGTON  The incoming national security adviser has called for the swift takeover of North Korea by the South. He and the newly nominated secretary of state have urged withdrawal from the 2015 nuclear deal with Iran. The pick for C.I.A. director once oversaw interrogations in which terrorism suspects were tortured.

title: Young Migrants Return to Mexico Is More Exile Than Homecoming
description: MEXICO CITY  Lalo Aguilar was born in the Mexican border city of Jurez 29 years ago, carries a Mexican passport and lives in Mexico City. Yet he speaks of Mexico as a kind of foreign country, a place to which he was banished.

title: Strong Reactions to U.S. Trade Moves
description: The White House, engaged in a trade dispute with China, has announced exemptions to steel and aluminum tariffs for several allies, including the European Union, and is marginalizing the World Trade Organization. Below is a selection of notable reactions to the protectionist moves.

title: Thousands March to End Gun Violence
description: On Saturday, hundreds of thousands of people poured into the streets in Washington and cities across the globe to take a stance against gun violence.

title: How Calls for Privacy May Upend Business for Facebook and Google
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The contemporary internet was built on a bargain: Show us who you really are and the digital world will be free to search or share.

title: Timeline: Facebook and Google Under Regulators Glare
description: Over the years, regulators on both sides of the Atlantic have cracked down on Facebook and Google for privacy violations. But as the European Union prepares to introduce comprehensive new data protection regulation in May, European regulators have been stepping up investigations into tech industry data practices.

title: Using Digital Firm, Brexit Campaigners Skirted Spending Laws, Ex-Employee Says
description: LONDON  Two senior advisers to Prime Minister Theresa May might have conspired to bypass electoral spending laws when they were leading a campaign for Britain to leave the European Union, a former employee of their effort said this week, in an interview and in testimony he gave to the countrys elections regulator.

title: Stop Asking About My Kids College Plans
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  The first time I drive with my daughter, she makes a left turn without putting on her blinker. She says: Want to know a funny thing about me? I never signal.

title: Dont Delete Facebook. Do Something About It.
description: On March 16, as the buzzer sounded in perhaps the worst upset in N.C.A.A. tournament history, and my beloved University of Virginia went down to the 16th-seeded University of Maryland, Baltimore County, I had one thought: I need to deactivate my Facebook account. I did not want to endure the taunts and trash talk of my friends who cheer for Duke.

title: A Hawk Takes Flight
description: Now that John Bolton has finally ascended from the limbo of the green room to the Valhalla of the White House, we need to settle the first question of his tenure: Is he a neocon or a paleocon?

title: Francis, the Anti-Strongman
description: VATICAN CITY  One recent Friday evening, Pope Francis presided over a penitential service at St. Peters. After the Gospel was read he strode beneath the great dome and knelt at a wooden booth, while other Catholics did likewise throughout the basilica. I am a sinner, he had said shortly after his election in 2013, and five years later the self-description still holds: Before going into the booth to listen as others confessed their sins, he confessed his own.

title: A Voodoo Curse on Human Traffickers
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  Human traffickers have officially been cursed. On March 9, Oba Ewuare II, the traditional ruler of the kingdom of Benin, in southern Nigeria, put a voodoo curse on anyone who abets illegal migration within his domain. At the same time, he revoked the curses that leave victims of trafficking afraid that their relatives will die if they go to the police or fail to pay off their debt.

title: Understanding Rural Americas Gun Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: The Man With the Battery-Powered Heart
description: His heart was failing. I imagine it was like this: His legs were swollen and heavy like weights. He was so tired. But when he lay down, he felt he was drowning, and so he started to sleep propped up on the couch. He had taken all the medicines his doctors prescribed him, and they each helped a little, but they did not help enough.

title: Why Lyndon Johnson Dropped Out
description: A half-century has passed since President Lyndon B. Johnson stunned Americans by announcing, in a televised address on March 31, 1968, that he was drastically reducing the bombing of North Vietnam, appealing to the Hanoi government for negotiations and, most incredible of all, withdrawing from the presidential election that fall. One imagines the stupefied reaction in living rooms all across the country: Did he just say what I think he said?

title: New York Forgets Its Juvenile Lifers
description: Carlos Flores was 17 when he and three accomplices tried to rob a bar in Queens, N.Y., in 1981. An off-duty police officer named Robert Walsh intervened, and he was shot and killed. Mr. Flores was convicted of second-degree murder, a conviction that carried a maximum sentence of 25 years to life in prison. But because he was not the shooter, the judge gave him 21 years to life.

title: Tariffs on Imports? What Exactly Is an Import?
description: When the New York International Auto Show opens on Friday, Audi will be featuring vehicles like the SQ5, one of the German automakers latest entries in the highly competitive S.U.V. market. Well appointed and high powered, the SQ5, which ranges in price from $54,300 to nearly $70,000 with options, competes with the likes of BMW, Lexus, Lincoln and Land Rover.

title: Bolt the Oval Against Bolton
description: WASHINGTON  Its unnerving covering a president who is treated like a boy king, requiring minders; who is easily swayed because he is underinformed; who can sit still only long enough for short oral briefings; who swaggers and mocks to mask his insecurities; who tries to replace real news with faux; and who cant seem to fathom that distorting reality to suit political ends is dangerous.

title: Are You Really in Love if Its Not on Instagram?
description: Look at this.

title: Drilling the Great Australian Bight: Hoping for Jobs, but Fearing a Spill
description: PORT LINCOLN, Australia  It has been called Australias answer to the Galpagos: a stretch of rich, pristine ocean facing the Antarctic that is home to calving whales and teeming fisheries that have turned local boat captains into tuna barons.

title: Stop Shielding Gun Makers
description: The survivors of the Parkland shooting have led a national call to action, and the nation has responded. Students have walked out of their schools in protest, businesses have cut ties with the N.R.A., and our collective frustration culminated in the March for Our Lives this weekend.

title: Stormy Daniels, Porn Star Suing Trump, Is Known for Her Ambition: Shes the Boss
description: One by one, the honorees came forward to be recognized: the wounded veteran, the tech executive and the noted porn star.

title: Were All in the Ghetto Now
description: LOS ANGELES  During President Trumps fund-raising trip to Beverly Hills, Calif., this month  the first time hed come to the official state of resistance since becoming president  a couple of friends of mine took to the streets, along with hundreds of others, to protest. But the visit was highly stage-managed, and Mr. Trump never faced the crowd; the most my friends could do, they said, was raise a middle finger to the sky as his aircraft flew overhead.

title: A 360-Degree View of the March for Our Lives Protest
description: Witness the thousands who have gathered on Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington to protest gun violence, in 360-degree video.

title: As Ties With Mexico Fray, Kushner Works Quietly to Mend Them
description: WASHINGTON  When President Trump complained that the $1.3 trillion spending bill he grudgingly signed on Friday did not pay for his border wall, he kept alive an issue that has poisoned relations between the United States and Mexico from the day he took office.

title: Follow the Sun
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Forgive me for repeating myself to the regulars, but for any Sunday-only solvers (or Wordplay readers), this weekend is the 41st annual American Crossword Puzzle Tournament. If youre interested in seeing how any of your fellow solvers and constructors are doing, theres lots of information on their site; if youre interested in a challenge, you can also buy the tournament puzzles to solve online.

title: For Parkland Students, a Surreal Journey From Normal to a Worldwide March
description: WASHINGTON  Little has returned to normal for the students of Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School since Feb. 14, when a gunman killed 14 of their classmates and three staff members.

title: A Last Holdout on Divorce, Philippines Tiptoes Toward Legalization
description: MANILA  Lennie Visbal last saw her husband, Joel, 13 years ago. Even then, she said, it was like looking at a stranger. But since divorce is not possible in the Philippines, Ms. Visbal cant escape him.

title: Greg Bird Removed From the Yankees Lineup With a Sore Right Foot
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Yankees first baseman Greg Bird, who has missed most of the last two seasons with injuries, was scratched from an exhibition game on Saturday and examined for discomfort in his right foot.

title: Mets Demote Zack Wheeler After a Weak Spring
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets demoted Zack Wheeler to Class AAA Las Vegas on Saturday after a weak spring training in which he surrendered 22 hits and nine earned runs over 10 innings.

title: Students Lead Huge Rallies for Gun Control Across the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  Standing before vast crowds from Washington to Los Angeles to Parkland, Fla., the speakers  nearly all of them students, some still in elementary school  delivered an anguished and defiant message: They are done hiding from gun violence, and will stop at nothing to get politicians to finally prevent it.

title: Friends and Family Wonder: Why Did the Austin Bomber Choose Us?
description: PFLUGERVILLE, Tex.  Mark Conditt, the man whose deadly bombing campaign terrorized Central Texas this month, occasionally got his hair cut at Deltons Pecan Street Barber Shop, less than a half-mile drive from his house in this sleepy suburb north of Austin.

title: Demonstrators Who Brought Guns and an Opposing Message: Shoot Back
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Dallas Johnson, 18, stood at the top of a hill here on Saturday, flanked by men with pistols and children gripping protest signs.

title: Michel Temer, Brazils Deeply Unpopular President, Signals Run for a New Term
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Michel Temer, the deeply unpopular president of Brazil, signaled that he intends to seek a full term in Octobers election, telling a newsmagazine in an interview published this weekend that it would be cowardly not to be a candidate.

title: After Early Miami Exit, Roger Federer Says Hell Skip the French Open
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  Roger Federer suffered one of the more shocking defeats of his career on Saturday, losing to a qualifier ranked 175th in a result that will also cost him the No. 1 ranking.

title: Loyola-Chicago Is in the Final Four After a Rout of Kansas State
description: ATLANTA  They had a mantra: believe, believe, believe. It came with a plan to be greedy and win one game, another, another and another. Now the Ramblers from Loyola of Chicago have turned a charmed N.C.A.A. tournament run into the ultimate journey for a college basketball team.

title: At Rallies, Students With a Different View of Gun Violence: As Urban Reality
description: WASHINGTON  Sprinkled amid the throngs of young people protesting gun violence in Washington on Saturday were groups of students without signs denouncing President Trump, or the National Rifle Association, or the shooting massacres that have plagued the nation.

title: A Top Candidate for New York Feds Leader: San Franciscos
description: John C. Williams, an economist and longtime Federal Reserve official, is a top candidate for president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, according to two people familiar with the search process.

title: What Emma Gonzlez Said Without Words at the March for Our Lives Rally
description: Emma Gonzlez spoke for just under two minutes on Saturday before tens of thousands of demonstrators at the March for Our Lives rally in Washington, describing the effects of gun violence in emotional detail and reciting the names of classmates who had been killed.

description: SPECIAL SECTION: WEALTH

title: Quotation of the Day: With Passion and Fury, Students March on Guns
description: If they continue to ignore us, to only pretend to listen, then we will take action where it counts. We will take action every day in every way until they simply cannot ignore us any more.

title: NCAA Basketball
description: The Ramblers from Loyola of Chicago routed Kansas State, 78-62, on Saturday to earn a trip to the Final Four for the first time since 1963.

title: Lisa Cohen, Hershel Kleinberg
description: Lisa Margaret Cohen and Hershel Alan Kleinberg are to be married March 25 at Stone Tower Winery, a vineyard and winery in Leesburg, Va. Paul R. Michel, a retired chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington, officiated.

description: Corinne Elizabeth Hagans and Derrick Arthur Morrison were married March 24 at the Yards Brewery in Philadelphia. Nathan Frew, an Assemblies of God pastor and a friend of the couple, officiated.

description: Randi Weingarten and Rabbi Sharon Anne Kleinbaum are to be married March 25 at La Marina, a restaurant in New York. Judge Michelle Schreiber of the New York City Housing Court, is to officiate, with Rabbi Sharon Cohen Anisfeld, the president of Hebrew College, leading the religious ceremony, which will include the signing of the ketubah.

description: Bill Hader stars as a hit man yearning for a new life in Barry. And Stormy Daniels breaks her silence on 60 Minutes.

title: Solving the Dutch Pot Paradox: Legal to Buy, but Not to Grow
description: BREDA, Netherlands  Acting on an anonymous tip about marijuana growers, Dutch police officers last month raided a basement laboratory in Best, a small village about 15 miles from the Belgian border.

title: China Splits Top Jobs at Central Bank, Adding Another Reformer
description: BEIJING  Less than a week after naming Yi Gang as the governor of Chinas central bank, leaders in Beijing have unexpectedly put a different man above him as the Communist Party secretary at the central bank, five people familiar with the decision said on Sunday.

description: BEIJING  Ms. Choi was worried about her sister in North Korea.
